author: nimrodyo
content: What's the reason for not running a full client on a mobile device after The Merge?

author: nimrodyo
content: I mean like a full node

author: shresth
content: Running a full execution + consensus client would require the similar amount of storage and network bandwidth similar to that of current full node. This is not possible to run on a mobile devide

author: nimrodyo
content: because of battery life and computation?

author: tersec
content: mainnet execution clients require hundreds of GBs of storage. The RAM might be there, though they typically want 16GB of RAM and mobile platforms such as Android and iOS are loathe to allow individual processes to use that. etc

author: nimrodyo
content: I assumed that after the merge, and after shards will be introduced, a full node will require less computation power

author: tersec
content: Whatever the future situation, the immediate post-merge situation won't have sharding (there are other EIPs addressing what sharding is/was supposed to)

author: jlokier
content: With the most compact current methods, it is now feasible store the Mainnet execution state database, pruned (recent 90k blocks worth), in a modern mobile phone's storage, even without sharding or the Portal Network DHT. Storing block bodies in Portal reduces the space needed, and that's the simplest part of Portal I think (the block bodies are effectively just simple files without complicated latency requirements or structure). But the battery will be drained if it's trying to keep up with the network. The computations are too intensive to run all day, and the constant radio communications will also drain the battery.
